{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3135197,"name":"Alex Chadwick","username":"Marsient","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/marsient/{size}/154894_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-28T01:25:13.995Z","cooked":"

Our team is making a robot with an extending arm that can score on any level with cones and cubes. We have a Limelight 2 and a mecanum drive. Our idea was to use the area and x-position of the AprilTag from the Limelight to move the robot into position to score without manually controlling it. The issue we’re having is how the driver would tell the robot what spot on the grid to score in. For example, there would be 9 buttons, corresponding to the 9 spots in each third of the grid; the driver would press button 1, activating a command that moves the robot to score in the top left spot. This is probably not the best way to do it but it’s all we could come up with. I’m happy to answer any questions about our robot that are needed to help. Even help brainstorming would be appreciated.

(our code for reference)

GitHub

GitHub - IcedJavaRobotics/2023-Charged-Up-Comptetition: we know the name is...

we know the name is misspelled and we most likely aren't doing anything about it - GitHub - IcedJavaRobotics/2023-Charged-Up-Comptetition: we know the name is misspelled and we most likely aren...

We have implemented a relatively simple algorithm for locating the nearest grid area to the robot on the fly. You can find it around line 124 in this file:

Edit: We do have multiple commands using this data to automatically drive to or aim at the nearest placement location (also depending on the level we are placing on). We bind those commands in RobotContainer and see the commands folder for more information.

github.com

FRC2539/javabot-2023/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/Constants.java

package frc.robot;

import com.ctre.phoenix.motorcontrol.NeutralMode;
import edu.wpi.first.apriltag.AprilTag;
import edu.wpi.first.apriltag.AprilTagFieldLayout;
import edu.wpi.first.apriltag.AprilTagFieldLayout.OriginPosition;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Pose2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Pose3d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Rotation3d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Transform2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Transform3d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation2d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.geometry.Translation3d;
import edu.wpi.first.math.kinematics.SwerveDriveKinematics;
import edu.wpi.first.math.util.Units;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DriverStation;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.DriverStation.Alliance;
import frc.lib.swerve.SecondOrderSwerveKinematics;
import frc.lib.swerve.SwerveModuleConstants;

One of the most tried and true methods of doing is to have your robot shift left or right based on it’s position according to the limelight. You have a mecanumDrive method.

Instead of using driver control for the y Value, what if that was instead a function that returned how “far off” the the target was according to your limelight. If your limelight return tx = 100 but the position you need to be in is 82, you might do

driveTrainSubsystem.mecanumDrive(x, (100 - 82)/10, 0);

in order to make it drive towards the right direction.
(Of course, you’ll actually have to replace 100 and 82 with variables/limelight methods in your code so it properly updates)

I’m intentionally leaving exact execution vague so you can think about this. I think your approach is a good great one, but will need some tuning. Ask any further questions you might need, I’m happy to get more specific.

We have created some code that should automatically strafe the robot to a specific position when an apriltag is seen and the button is held down. Will someone please look through this to make sure our robot will not explode as soon as we turn it on with this code?

In all seriousness, any advice on a better way to do this would be wonderful. The way we’re doing it now just seems very messy.
